title: What is the relationship between the new religion and the democratic germ, and how do contemporary movements try to reconcile spiritual evolution with human values?
first_phrase: The final 200 words of this text discuss the development of spiritual organizations and movements that connect the concept of salvation with individual belief and adoption of certain practices or beliefs. The author highlights that some of these groups have managed to integrate scientific theories of evolution into their spiritual beliefs and practices. The text also mentions the psychological motive of fear of divine wrath common in both the Old and New Testaments. The author notes that some of these groups have esoteric teachings or seek initiation, while others focus on moral values. Ultimately, the text suggests that the belief in salvation and inherent equality among people remains a prevalent and significant concept in Christianity and beyond.

last_phrase: In conclusion, it is important to remember that belief in the Son guarantees eternal life as stated in the New Testament, but those who do not believe will face the wrath of God. The fear of this divine anger is often emphasized in the Bible; however, it is important to note that according to Paul and Luke, God is slow to anger. There are many organizations that claim to be initiatory and promote esoteric doctrines, but evolution leads everyone to progress and access higher stages of spiritual development. Despite the fact that this "school of life" may consist mainly of repeaters and fools, the power of evolution eventually propels everyone forward, and Karma and reincarnation are means by which to mature and progress.
